processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: Prior to 2024, the various business records in this collection were originally described as individual records, but they have been consolidated into one large business record for the locality.

The records in this collection were processed in 2022 by Greg Crawford. Efforts have been taken to identify chancery causes related to these business records as some of these records were used as evidence in court proceedings.

bioghist.head: Historical Information
bioghist.p: Context for Record Type: Business Records, both volumes and loose records, are in some cases transferred to the Library of Virginia as components of court record transfers. These business records in some cases were simply stored in the local court building for safe keeping by business owners. In other cases, business records (particularly ledgers, account books, etc.) may have been filed in a court case as an exhibit. These business record exhibits appeared both in chancery causes and in judgments, these records serving as exhibits for business dissolution cases, debut suits, and contract disputes.
Locality History:King William County was named for William III and was formed from King and Queen County in 1701. Its area is 285.7 square miles, and the county seat is King William.
Lost Locality Notes: Created by an act of 1701 to take effect on April 11, 1702. Most records were destroyed by a courthouse fire on January 17, 1885. Only a few order books and deed books exist.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content
scopecontent.p: King William County (Va.) Business Records, 1855-1878, is currently compromised of records created by the West Point Land Company. Represented records largely consists of journals, ledgers, and daybooks.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: This collection is arranged into one series:

did.unittitle: West Point Land Company Business Records 1855-1878

scopecontent.p: Historical Information:Volumes were used as exhibits in the chancery cause Richmond Bland etc. vs. Town of West Point heard in the Circuit Court of King William County.
Scope and Content: West Point Land Company Business Records, 1855-1878 consists of a journal, ledger, and daybook that record the financial transactions of the West Point Land Company.
See also: King William County (Va.) Chancery Causes, 1906-016: Richmond Bland etc. vs. Town of West Point
